message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The PIG-A gene mutation causes a deficiency in glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI)-anchored proteins, including CD55 and CD59. So CD55 will be negative in the flow cytometry test for his condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The PIG-A gene mutation affects the ability of cells to create glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchors, which are necessary for attaching certain proteins to the cell surface, including CD55 (also known as decay-accelerating factor or DAF). Therefore, CD55 will be negative in the flow cytometry test for this condition. The other markers listed are unrelated to this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The PIG-A gene is involved in the production of glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchors which attach proteins to cell membranes. The absence of CD55 on erythrocytes is a hallmark of PIG-A gene mutations, resulting in complement-mediated hemolysis and pink-tinged urine. CD19, CD40L, and CD3 are not relevant in the diagnosis of this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The PIG-A gene encodes a protein necessary for the synthesis of the glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchor, which attaches proteins to the cell surface. The absence of GPI-anchored proteins on hematopoietic cells results in the development of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH). Among the options given, only CD55 and CD59, two GPI-anchored proteins, will be absent or reduced in PNH. Therefore, the correct answer is CD55.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. PIG-A gene is involved in the biosynthesis of glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchors. Without GPI anchors, CD55 and CD59 are not expressed on the cell membrane. Therefore, CD55 will be negative in flow cytometry for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The condition described is paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH), which is caused by a mutation in the PIG-A gene, leading to a deficiency of glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) on cell surfaces. CD55 (decay-accelerating factor) and CD59 (membrane inhibitor of reactive lysis), which are GPI-anchored proteins, are often absent or decreased in PNH. Therefore, the correct answer is CD55.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. An acquired defect in PIG-A gene causes paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH), which results in hemolytic anemia and pink-tinged urine due to hemoglobinuria. Among the options, only CD55 is a marker for the PNH defect and hence will be negative in flow cytometry test for this condition. CD19, CD40L, and CD3 are markers for B-cells, activated T-cells, and T-cells, respectively, and are not related to PNH.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. PIG-A gene mutation causes paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria, which leads to a deficiency of glycosylphosphatidylinositol-anchored proteins. CD55 is a GPI-anchored protein, so it will be negative in the flow cytometry test for this condition. The other markers listed are not specific to this condition.

We refer to a medical journal article on paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) for help. PNH is caused by a mutation of the PIG-A gene, leading to a lack of GPI-anchored proteins. CD55 is a GPI-anchored protein, so it will be negative in flow cytometry tests for PNH. The other markers are not related to PNH.

We refer to Mayo Clinic's website for help. PNH (paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria) is a disorder caused by a defect in a stem cell that results in the absence of normal proteins on the surface of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets. CD55 is a marker that is absent in PNH.
